prompt: Facts: The case involves an appeal by Ravi alias Ravichandran (A1) against his conviction for murder.; A1 (Ravi), A2 (Munuswamy), and A3 (Babu) were charged with the murder of Raji (wife of A1).; Incident occurred during the night intervening 30.09.1995 and 01.10.1995 at the residence of A1 and the deceased in MGR Nagar, Chennai.; Prosecution alleged motive: A1 had an illicit relationship with Vasantha (wife of A2). The deceased (Raji) objected to this relationship, leading to frequent quarrels.; Allegation: A1, A2, and A3 conspired and murdered Raji. A1 allegedly strangulated her with a rope (M.O.1), while A2 and A3 held her legs.; PW1 (brother of the deceased) filed the complaint.; Post-mortem examination (conducted by PW4) revealed the cause of death as asphyxia due to strangulation, noting a ligature mark on the neck.; Key prosecution witnesses included PW1 (complainant, deposed about motive/quarrels), PW2 (neighbour, initially hostile, later partially supported prosecution regarding quarrels), PW3 (neighbour, deposed about motive/quarrels).; A1 allegedly made a confessional statement leading to the recovery of the rope (M.O.1) under Section 27 of the Indian Evidence Act.; Trial Court: Convicted A1 under Section 302 IPC and sentenced him to life imprisonment. Acquitted A2 and A3.; High Court: Confirmed the conviction and sentence of A1. The State did not appeal against the acquittal of A2 and A3.; Supreme Court: A1 appealed against the High Court's judgment confirming his conviction. | IPC: Section 302 (Punishment for Murder), Section 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention) - Primarily relevant at trial stage for A2/A3, implicitly considered regarding A1's sole act.
completion: {"prosecution": [{"argument": "A1's guilt for murder under Section 302 IPC is proven beyond reasonable doubt through a complete chain of circumstantial evidence.", "precedents": ["Sharad Birdhichand Sarda v. State of Maharashtra (1984) 4 SCC 116", "Hanumant Govind Nargundkar v. State of M.P. AIR 1952 SC 343", "State of U.P. v. Ashok Kumar Srivastava (1992) 2 SCC 86"]}, {"argument": "Strong motive (illicit relationship and deceased's objections leading to quarrels) is established through witness testimony (PW1, PW2, PW3), strengthening the circumstantial case.", "precedents": ["Suresh Chandra Bahri v. State of Bihar AIR 1994 SC 2420", "Nathuni Yadav v. State of Bihar (1998) 9 SCC 238", "G. Parshwanath v. State of Karnataka (2010) 8 SCC 593"]}, {"argument": "Recovery of the weapon (rope - M.O.1) at the instance of A1 under Section 27 of the Evidence Act corroborates his involvement.", "precedents": ["Pulukuri Kottaya v. Emperor AIR 1947 PC 67", "Mohd. Inayatullah v. State of Maharashtra (1976) 1 SCC 828", "State of Karnataka v. David Rozario (2002) 7 SCC 728"]}, {"argument": "Medical evidence (post-mortem report by PW4) clearly establishes homicidal death by strangulation, consistent with the prosecution's case of murder by A1 using a rope.", "precedents": ["Balbir Singh v. State of Punjab (2006) 12 SCC 149", "Kehar Singh v. State (Delhi Admn.) (1988) 3 SCC 609", "Mulla v. State of U.P. (2010) 3 SCC 508"]}], "defense": [{"argument": "The prosecution case relies solely on circumstantial evidence, and the chain is not complete; crucial links are missing or weak, failing the standard set by Sharad Birdhichand Sarda.", "precedents": ["Sharad Birdhichand Sarda v. State of Maharashtra (1984) 4 SCC 116", "Sujit Biswas v. State of Assam (2013) 12 SCC 406", "Ashish Jain v. Makrand Singh (2019) 3 SCC 770"]}, {"argument": "The alleged recovery of the rope (M.O.1) under Section 27 Evidence Act is unreliable and does not conclusively link A1 to the crime.", "precedents": ["Asar Mohammad v. State of U.P. (2019) 12 SCC 253", "Pankaj Kumar Singh v. State of Jharkhand (2021) 11 SCC 600", "Bobcombe Cannu v. State of Karnataka (2022) SCC Online SC 1489"]}, {"argument": "The testimonies of PW1 (brother) and PW3 (neighbour) regarding motive are biased and interested; PW2's testimony is unreliable due to initial hostility. Lack of independent corroboration.", "precedents": ["Hari Obula Reddy v. State of A.P. (1981) 3 SCC 675", "Sachin Kumar Singhraha v. State of Madhya Pradesh (2019) 6 SCC 55", "Raju v. State of Haryana (2010) 3 SCC 235"]}, {"argument": "Acquittal of A2 and A3 weakens the overall prosecution story, especially the conspiracy angle and the alleged manner of holding the deceased.", "precedents": ["Brathi v. State of Punjab (1991) 1 SCC 519 (Discrepancy between charge and finding)", "State of Rajasthan v. Kishore (1996) 3 SCC 217 (Impact of acquittal of co-accused)", "Insufficient data - Specific precedents on how co-accused acquittal impacts remaining conviction based on circumstantial evidence would require deeper search."]}]}
